description: From Middle English leyen, leggen, from Old English leċġan (“to lay”), from Proto-West Germanic *laggjan, from Proto-Germanic *lagjaną (“to lay”), causative form of Proto-Germanic *ligjaną (“to lie, recline”), from Proto-Indo-European *legʰ- (“to lie, recline”).

Cognate with West Frisian lizze (“to lay, to lie”), Dutch leggen (“to lay”), German legen (“to lay”), Norwegian Bokmål legge (“to lay”), Norwegian Nynorsk leggja (“to lay”), Swedish lägga (“to lay”), Icelandic leggja (“to lay”), Albanian lag (“troop, band, war encampment”).

entries.meaning: Arrangement or relationship; layout.
examples: the lay of the land

entries.meaning: A share of the profits in a business.
The direction a rope is twisted.
examples: Worm and parcel with the lay; turn and serve the other way.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) A casual sexual partner.
examples: What was I, just another lay you can toss aside as you go on to your next conquest?

entries.meaning: (colloquial) An act of sexual intercourse.
(slang, archaic) A place or activity where someone spends a significant portion of their time.
examples: I shall be on that lay nae mair

entries.meaning: The laying of eggs.
examples: The hens are off the lay at present.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A layer.
examples: […]   lay in the bottom of an earthen pot some dried vine leaves, and so make a lay of Pears, and leaves till the pot is filled up, laying betwixt each lay some sliced Ginger  […]

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A basis or ground.

verbs.description: lay (third-person singular simple present lays, present participle laying, simple past and past participle laid)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To place down in a position of rest, or in a horizontal position.
examples: to lay a book on the table;   to lay a body in the grave
A shower of rain lays the dust.

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To cause to subside or abate.
examples: Synonyms: becalm, settle down

entries.meaning: (transitive) To prepare (a plan, project etc.); to set out, establish (a law, principle).
(transitive) To install certain building materials, laying one thing on top of another.
examples: lay brick;  lay flooring

entries.meaning: (transitive) To produce and deposit an egg.
examples: the hen laid an egg
Did dinosaurs lay their eggs in a nest?

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bet (that something is or is not the case).
examples: I'll lay that he doesn't turn up on Monday.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To deposit (a stake) as a wager; to stake; to risk.
examples: He laid a hundred guineas with the laird of Slofferfield that he would drive four horses through the Slofferfield loch, and in the prank he had his bit chariot dung to pieces and a good mare killed.

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To have sex with.
examples: Synonyms: lie by, lie with, sleep with; see also Thesaurus:copulate with

entries.meaning: (nautical) To take a position; to come or go.
examples: to lay forward;  to lay aloft

entries.meaning: (law) To state; to allege.
examples: to lay the venue

entries.meaning: (military) To point; to aim.
examples: to lay a gun

entries.meaning: (ropemaking) To put the strands of (a rope, a cable, etc.) in their proper places and twist or unite them.
examples: to lay a cable or rope

entries.meaning: (printing) To place and arrange (pages) for a form upon the imposing stone.
(printing) To place (new type) properly in the cases.
To apply; to put.
To impose (a burden, punishment, command, tax, etc.).
examples: to lay a tax on land

entries.meaning: To impute; to charge; to allege.
examples: Synonyms: ascribe, attribute

entries.meaning: To present or offer.
examples: to lay an indictment in a particular county
I have laid the facts of the matter before you.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, proscribed, see usage notes) To lie: to rest in a horizontal position on a surface.
examples: I found him laying on the floor.

description: From Middle English laie, lawe, from Old English lagu (“sea, flood, water, ocean”), from Proto-West Germanic *lagu (“water, sea”), from Proto-Germanic *laguz (“water, sea”), from Proto-Indo-European *lókus (“water, body of water, lake”). Cognate with Icelandic lögur (“liquid, fluid, lake”), Latin lacus (“lake, hollow, hole”).

entries.meaning: A lake.

description: From Middle English lay, from Old French lai, from Latin laicus, from Ancient Greek λαϊκός (laïkós). Doublet of laic.

adjectives.description: lay (comparative more lay, superlative most lay)

entries.meaning: Not belonging to the clergy, but associated with them.
examples: They seemed more lay than clerical.
a lay preacher; a lay brother

entries.meaning: Non-professional; not being a member of an organized institution.
(card games) Not trumps.
examples: a lay suit

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Not educated or cultivated; ignorant.

description: See lie. This word was influenced by the present tense verb lay.

entries.meaning: simple past tense of lie when pertaining to position.
examples: The baby lay in its crib and slept silently.

entries.meaning: (proscribed) To be in a horizontal position; to lie (from confusion with lie).
examples: Lay, lady, lay. / Lay across my big brass bed.

description: From Middle English lay, from Old French lai (“song, lyric, poem”), from Frankish *laih (“play, melody, song”), from Proto-Germanic *laikaz, *laikiz (“jump, play, dance, hymn”), from Proto-Indo-European *leyg- (“to jump, spring, play”). Akin to Old High German leih (“a play, skit, melody, song”), Middle High German leich (“piece of music, epic song played on a harp”), Old English lācan (“to move quickly, fence, sing”). See lake.

entries.meaning: A ballad or sung poem; a short poem or narrative, usually intended to be sung.
examples: I strive, with wakeful melody, to cheer
The sullen gloom, sweet Philomel! like thee,
And call the stars to listen: every star
Is deaf to mine, enamour'd of thy lay.

entries.meaning: A lyrical, narrative poem written in octosyllabic couplets that often deals with tales of adventure and romance.
examples: Sad is the note and sad the lay, but mirth we meet not every day.

description: From Middle English lay, laye, laiȝe, leyȝe, from Old English lǣh, lēh, northern (Anglian) variants of Old English lēah (“lea”). More at lea.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A meadow; a lea.

description: From Middle English laige, læȝe, variants of Middle English lawe (“law”). More at law.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A law.
(obsolete) An obligation; a vow.
examples: they bound themselues by a sacred lay and oth to fight it out to the last man

description: Calque of Yiddish לייגן‎ (leygn, “to put, lay”).

verbs.description: lay (third-person singular simple present lays, present participle laying, simple past and past participle laid)

entries.meaning: (Judaism, transitive) To don or put on (tefillin (phylacteries)).
